summary: **noun / slang.** A record pressed with the lead-in groove unusually short.
definition: **noun / slang.** A record pressed with the lead-in groove unusually short — almost shaped like a "J" hugging the label — meaning the song starts very close to the label. This pressing technique emerged in the 1960s as labels sought to maximize playing time on 7-inch singles, particularly when cramming longer album tracks onto 45s. The abbreviated lead-in creates an abrupt visual transition from label to modulated groove, making these pressings instantly recognizable. DJs initially disliked J-cuts because the reduced cueing space made needle drops more difficult, requiring precise hand-eye coordination to avoid starting mid-phrase. The practice became more common in the 1970s with disco 12-inches and promotional singles where every second of groove real estate mattered. Collectors today view certain J-cut pressings as desirable variants, particularly on rare soul and funk 45s where the unusual cut sometimes indicates a specific pressing plant or early run. The term remains studio and collector slang rather than official pressing terminology.
etymology: Coined by record collectors and DJs in the 1970s, referencing the visual resemblance of the abbreviated lead-in groove to the letter "J" curving tightly around the label edge.
